title: 106_hr1625
content: The "Human Rights Information Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. The findings section of the Act highlights key information. Congress finds that the national and international protection of human rights is a priority for the United States. Federal agencies possess documents on human rights violations abroad that are needed by foreign authorities for investigation and prosecution. Requests for legal assistance from foreign authorities regarding human rights will continue to be received by the United States. The United States receives requests from foreign authorities for legal assistance on human rights violations, including declassification of documents. Requests have come from Guatemala, Honduras, and a Spanish court magistrate regarding General Augusto Pinochet. The US follows procedures outlined in Presidential directives and executive orders to respond to declassification requests, aiming to strengthen existing procedures for the protection and promotion of human rights nationally and internationally. The United States aims to strengthen declassification procedures for human rights documents to protect global human rights, enhance accountability of Federal agencies, and save Government resources. This commitment is crucial for promoting and protecting human rights and democracy worldwide. The United States is committed to promoting human rights and democracy globally through diplomatic, economic, and military efforts. This includes support from NGOs and citizens, but these efforts are hindered if countries continue to ignore human rights violations, potentially leading to renewed US engagements in those areas. The United States has a significant interest in newly established democratic societies taking credible steps to investigate and prosecute human rights violations to end impunity. This can involve creating truth commissions, appointing human rights officers, or conducting national investigations with the help of civil society organizations. The US has historically led efforts to end impunity for gross human rights violations globally. The United States has played a key role in promoting international efforts to end impunity for human rights violations by supporting various war crimes tribunals and ratifying the Convention against Torture. The United States is obligated to provide assistance in criminal proceedings related to torture and adopt measures for free access to information in cases of human rights violations. The Guatemalan peace accords, supported by the United States, included an investigation by the Clarification Commission to uncover human rights violations and acts of violence. Despite the investigation's conclusion, many questions remain unanswered regarding perpetrators and the whereabouts of the disappeared. The Clarification Commission recommended that the Guatemalan Government use all resources to find the disappeared and return their remains to relatives. Two days after presenting a parallel investigation, Bishop Juan Jose Gerardi, director of the Historical Memory Recovery Project, was assassinated. President Clinton emphasized the importance of the United States' relationship with Guatemala during his visit in 1999. The director of the Historical Memory Recovery Project in Guatemala, Bishop Juan Jose Gerardi, was assassinated. President Clinton condemned support for military forces involved in repression and emphasized continued support for peace in Guatemala. The National Commissioner for Human Rights in Honduras has been seeking US documentation on human rights violations since 1993. The National Commissioner for Human Rights in Honduras has been requesting US documentation on human rights violations since 1993, with some aspects still pending. The National Commissioner for Human Rights in Honduras has been requesting US documentation on human rights violations since 1993, with some aspects still pending. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "human rights record" refers to information on gross violations of human rights post-1944 held by the US Government. "Agency" includes entities involved in foreign policy or intelligence. The term "gross violations of internationally recognized human rights" is defined in section 502B(d)(1) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. It includes actions by various government agencies such as the Department of Justice, National Security Council, and Executive Office of the President. SEC. 4. IDENTIFICATION, REVIEW, AND PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF HUMAN RIGHTS RECORDS REGARDING GUATEMALA AND HONDURAS. The Act governs the declassification and public disclosure of human rights records by agencies, specifically focusing on activities in Guatemala and Honduras after 1944. Agencies must identify, review, and organize these records for declassification within 120 days. The President must report to Congress on agency compliance within 150 days. Grounds for postponement of public disclosure of records are outlined in section 5. An agency can delay public disclosure of a human rights record if it poses a serious threat to national security, outweighing the public interest, and reveals sensitive intelligence information. The public disclosure of a human rights record can be delayed if it relates to military defense, intelligence operations, or foreign relations of the United States and would impair national security. The public disclosure of a human rights record can be delayed if it would impair national security, reveal confidential information, invade personal privacy, or compromise confidentiality agreements. The public disclosure of a human rights record may be postponed if it would harm national security, breach confidentiality agreements, or invade personal privacy. Special treatment is given to information regarding individuals who were intelligence assets of the US government. SEC. 6 states that if a US agency receives a request for human rights records from certain international entities or countries investigating human rights violations, they must review and disclose the records according to the standards in the Act. SEC. 7 addresses the review process for decisions to withhold records. The Appeals Panel reviews agency determinations to postpone public disclosure of human rights records. They will direct disclosure unless there is clear evidence that the record is not a human rights record or qualifies for postponement. The Appeals Panel reviews agency decisions to postpone disclosure of human rights records. If the Panel agrees with the agency's decision, they will determine alternative forms of disclosure, such as releasing a portion of the record after removing sensitive information. The Appeals Panel reviews agency decisions on disclosing human rights records. Alternative forms of disclosure include releasing a portion of the record after removing sensitive information, providing a substitute record, or a summary of the information. The Panel notifies the agency head of its determination within 14 days. The Appeals Panel notifies the agency head and President of its determination on human rights record disclosure within 14 days. Guidelines for adjudicating appeals are published in the Federal Register. Presidential authority over Appeals Panel determination is outlined. The Appeals Panel publishes guidelines in the Federal Register for adjudicating appeals. The President has the authority to review and make decisions on Appeals Panel determinations within 30 days, based on specified standards. The President must provide the Appeals Panel with a written certification explaining the decision to postpone disclosure of a human rights record, including the standards for the determination. The Appeals Panel will then publish the President's certification in the Federal Register. SEC. 8. The Information Security Policy Advisory Council will report to Congress on declassifying human rights records of other countries. SEC. 9. Ensures the Freedom of Information Act and judicial review rights are not limited. SEC. 10. Creation of positions. SEC. 10. Creation of 2 additional positions in the Appeals Panel for individuals with substantial human rights expertise appointed by the President with recommendations from human rights organizations.
